title: ChatGPT-like Multimodal Conversational Platform (Global, Real-time, Multi-LLM)
overview: A globally distributed, real-time conversational AI platform supporting multi-turn chat with multiple LLM backends, multimodal inputs, and rich history management. The system is built for 20M DAUs and 500M messages/day with sub-500ms time-to-first-token via a high-performance WebSocket gateway, an LLM routing layer with fast failover, and region-affine, strongly consistent storage for conversation history. Analytics, cost tracking, and admin observability are first-class through an events pipeline into ClickHouse and Prometheus/Grafana. The core data plane is stateless, horizontally scalable on Kubernetes, and tolerant of provider or regional failures.

functional: User authentication (OAuth/social SSO) and session management
Create/read/update/delete multi-turn conversations and messages with context retention
Real-time streaming of assistant responses over WebSocket (token-by-token)
Conversation history: search, star, tag, foldering, archive, delete
Multiple model selection across providers and in-house inference
Rate limiting and quota enforcement by user/tier and per-model
File upload for images/documents with virus scan, OCR/text extraction, and multimodal prompt support
Share conversations via public links with configurable visibility
Admin dashboard: model/provider health, usage, cost, errors, rate limits/quota states
Cost tracking per request for accurate billing and cost attribution
nonFunctional: Support ≥100K concurrent WebSocket connections per region
Regional fault tolerance and LLM provider failover with graceful degradation
Horizontal scalability to 500M messages/day (60k msgs/sec peak)
Security: WAF, DDoS protection, encryption in transit/at rest, least-privilege IAM
Observability: distributed tracing, metrics, logs, audit trails
Privacy and compliance readiness (GDPR/CCPA data subject controls)
Cost efficiency: autoscaling compute/GPU, cost-aware routing, storage tiering

components.name: Client Web App
components.responsibility: SPA for chat UI, Markdown rendering, code highlighting, WebSocket streaming, file uploads, search, and sharing
components.techChoice: Next.js + React, TypeScript, WebSocket, highlight.js, Markdown-it
components.justification: Mature ecosystem, SSR for SEO (shared links), excellent dev productivity and performance

components.name: Edge CDN/WAF & Global LB
components.responsibility: TLS termination, caching static assets, DDoS/WAF, geo-steering to nearest healthy region
components.techChoice: Cloudflare CDN + Cloudflare Load Balancer + Bot Management
components.justification: Global footprint, anycast, robust WAF and health-based geo-routing to meet latency and availability targets

components.name: API & WebSocket Gateway
components.responsibility: Single entry for REST and WebSocket; authZ/authN checks, rate limiting, session validation, request fan-out to internal services; streams tokens to client
components.techChoice: Go microservice on Kubernetes with NGINX Ingress (ALB) and HTTP/2; gorilla/websocket; gRPC to internal services
components.justification: Go delivers low-latency IO and high concurrency; stable WS handling; NGINX Ingress + ALB scale well

components.name: Auth Service
components.responsibility: User identity, OAuth/social login, JWT issuance, refresh tokens, RBAC/roles (user/admin)
components.justification: Fast to integrate, enterprise SSO, adaptive MFA; offloads identity risk; standards-compliant OIDC

components.name: Rate Limit & Quota Service
components.responsibility: Enforces per-user/tier rate limits (sliding window) and quotas; provides near-real-time counters
components.techChoice: Envoy Global Rate Limit Service + Redis Cluster; Lua in NGINX for shadow checks
components.justification: Envoy RLS is battle-tested; Redis offers sub-ms counters and atomicity with Lua scripts

components.name: Session/Cache Store
components.responsibility: JWT blacklist, session metadata, ephemeral streaming buffers, recent context window cache
components.techChoice: Redis Cluster (6.x) with Redis Streams for ephemeral events
components.justification: In-memory speed, high availability via clustering and replication

components.name: Conversation Service
components.responsibility: CRUD for conversations/messages, context building, sharing ACLs, foldering/tags; transactional writes
components.techChoice: PostgreSQL (Citus) multi-tenant sharded by user_id; Go service using pgx
components.justification: Immediate consistency and SQL semantics; Citus scales horizontally and keeps p95 low with partitioning

components.name: Search/Indexing Service
components.responsibility: Full-text search over titles/messages; semantic search via embeddings; indexing pipeline
components.techChoice: OpenSearch (multi-az) + k-NN plugin; background workers (Go) for indexing
components.justification: Scalable search with near real-time indexing; k-NN for semantic search without extra vector DB

components.name: LLM Router
components.responsibility: Model catalog, routing to providers/in-house; health checks, circuit breakers, retries, cost-aware selection; streaming token multiplexing
components.techChoice: Go service with gobreaker, HTTP/2 keep-alive pools; provider SDKs; configuration via Consul/etcd
components.justification: Low-latency, robust control plane with per-provider health and dynamic routing rules

components.name: Provider Connectors
components.responsibility: Integrations to external LLMs and embeddings
components.techChoice: Connectors for "OpenAI/Anthropic/Azure OpenAI/Google Vertex"; retries with exponential backoff; streaming adapters
components.justification: Diversity reduces provider risk and enables cost/performance optimization

components.name: In-house Inference Cluster
components.responsibility: Self-hosted models (vLLM) for failover and cost control; embeddings server
components.techChoice: vLLM on Kubernetes GPU nodes (NVIDIA A10/A100), Triton for embeddings; Istio for mTLS
components.justification: High throughput, streaming-friendly; cost-efficient for baseline models and embeddings

components.name: File Ingestion Service
components.responsibility: Pre-signed uploads, virus scanning, OCR/text extraction, chunking; links assets to messages
components.techChoice: Amazon S3 + S3 Object Lambda (virus scan with ClamAV) + AWS Textract + Apache Tika; Step Functions for orchestration
components.justification: Serverless pipeline scales elastically; S3 durability and cost efficiency for blobs

components.name: Cost & Billing Service
components.responsibility: Compute per-request cost (provider rates, tokens, GPU time), store usage, expose invoices and quotas
components.techChoice: Kafka consumers (Go) -> ClickHouse for analytics; Postgres for authoritative balances
components.justification: ClickHouse excels at high-ingest analytics; Postgres for transactional balances and limits

components.name: Event Bus
components.responsibility: Asynchronous events: usage, costs, audit logs, indexing triggers
components.justification: High-throughput, durable event streaming; ecosystem support

components.name: Analytics & Monitoring
components.techChoice: Prometheus + Grafana; OpenTelemetry + Jaeger; Loki for logs; CloudWatch for infra

components.name: Admin Dashboard
components.responsibility: Operational UI: usage, costs, errors, provider health, throttles; model catalog management
components.justification: Unified operational control plane with low-latency analytics queries

dataStorage.justification: Strong consistency and transactions for conversations/messages; Citus provides horizontal sharding by user_id with high write throughput and low-latency queries
Sub-millisecond counters for rate limits, sessions, ephemeral streaming buffers, and hot context windows
Durable, cost-effective storage for file uploads, images, and large attachments; lifecycle policies for tiering
Full-text and semantic search with k-NN; scalable indexing and near real-time search for conversation history
Durable, scalable event streaming for usage, billing, indexing, and audit logs decoupling producers/consumers
High-ingest, columnar analytics for usage and cost reporting; sub-second aggregations at scale

apiDesign.description: Bidirectional WebSocket for sending user messages and receiving token-streaming responses and events
Create a new conversation (title, tags, model selection, visibility)
List conversations with filters (folder, tag, starred) and pagination
Get a conversation with messages (server-side pagination)
Add a user message to a conversation (text, file refs, tool calls)
Get message detail and streaming status
List available models and tiers, pricing metadata
Initiate file upload and get pre-signed URL; returns file_id
Per-user usage and remaining quota by period
Admin: provider health, error rates, throughput, cost summaries
Admin: manage model catalog, routing weights, and availability

scalabilityStrategy:
- Traffic and sessions: Anycast via Cloudflare to nearest region. Sticky session not required; WebSocket connections are long-lived and evenly distributed via ALB. Gateway pods autoscale on CPU and open FDs; each Go pod targets ~4–5K concurrent WS; 30 pods suffice for 150K WS with headroom per region.
- Storage: Citus shards by user_id across nodes; co-locate primary and replicas in same AZ to minimize latency. Connection pooling with PgBouncer. Hot partitions handled by rebalancing shards. PITR and logical replication to DR region.
- Search: OpenSearch domain scales horizontally across data nodes. Index with 1–3 primary shards per index and ILM for rollover. Async indexers consume from Kafka for sustained throughput.
- LLM routing: Health probes and circuit breakers per provider/region; latency-aware load balancing and hedged requests before first token. In-house vLLM autoscaling on GPU metrics (queue depth, tokens/sec). Keep-alive HTTP/2 pools to reduce TTFB.
- Rate limiting: Redis Cluster with hash tags for per-user keys ensures single-shard updates. Use sliding window with Lua for atomicity. Quotas aggregated periodically from ClickHouse and persisted to Postgres for authority.
- WebSockets: Separate HPA based on concurrent connections and network IO. Use SO_REUSEPORT and pod anti-affinity. Idle pings to detect dead peers. Backpressure controls to avoid OOM.
- Multi-region: Active-active per region; users are region-affined based on home region stored in profile. Cross-region failover via Cloudflare LB health checks; if home region is down, read last durable snapshot from DR and write to degraded mode (queue for backfill) with user-notice.
- Observability: OpenTelemetry traces propagate across gateway, LLM router, connectors. SLO-based autoscaling and alerting for TTFT and error budgets.

tradeoffs.decision: Use PostgreSQL (Citus) for conversations instead of a globally-distributed DB (e.g., Spanner/CockroachDB)
pros: Immediate consistency and strong SQL semantics
cons: Requires shard management and regional affinity policies

tradeoffs.decision: WebSockets for streaming vs Server-Sent Events
pros: Better concurrency characteristics and fewer HTTP headers

tradeoffs.decision: OpenSearch for full-text + k-NN vs separate vector DB
pros: Single search stack reduces ops overhead
Near real-time indexing with scalable ingestion
cons: k-NN recall/latency may trail specialized vector DBs
Index tuning and memory footprint can be heavy

tradeoffs.decision: Auth0 for identity instead of building in-house
pros: Security updates and compliance handled by vendor
cons: Rate limits and token introspection latency considerations

tradeoffs.decision: Kafka + ClickHouse for analytics and cost tracking
In-house vLLM cluster as secondary routing target
cons: Requires GPU capacity management and model maintenance
May lag on latest proprietary model capabilities

tradeoffs.decision: Async indexing to OpenSearch (eventual) while DB is immediate
pros: Protects write path latency and TTFT
cons: Search results may lag by seconds
Requires reconciliation jobs for rare failures
